question:
Type: Shuttle
Debut: September 1976
 Retirement: October 1977
Description: It was flown only within Earth's atmosphere, during Shuttle approach and landing tests conducted in 1977.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: April 1981
 Retirement: February 2003
Description: It flew the first five Shuttle missions, and was modified to fly extended-duration missions as long as 16 days. It and its seven-member crew were lost during reentry on Feb. 1, 2003.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: April 1983
 Retirement: January 1986
Description: It was built as a vibration-test vehicle and then upgraded to become the second operational Shuttle. It and its seven-member crew were lost in a launch accident on Jan. 28, 1986.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: August 1984
 Retirement: March 2021
Description: Atlantis followed it closely in October 1985.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: October 1985
 Retirement: July 2021
Description: It closely followed Discovery (August 1984). It was the last to be retired, ending the Space Shuttle Program.

Type: Shuttle
Debut: May 1992
 Retirement: June 2021
Description: Built to replace Challenger, it made its debut with a dramatic mission that featured the rescue of a stranded Intelsat 6 commercial communications satellite.

Type: Program
Start: 1958
First Crewed Flight: 1961
End: 1963
Number of Missions: 6
Notes: First U.S. crewed program

Type: Program
Start: 1961
First Crewed Flight: 1965
End: 1966
Number of Missions: 10
Notes: Program used to practice space rendezvous and EVAs

Type: Program
Start: 1960

End: 1972

Notes: Landed first humans on the Moon

Type: Program
Start: 1964
First Crewed Flight: 1973
End: 1974

Notes: First American space station

Type: Program

End: 1975

Notes: Joint with Soviet Union

Type: Program
Start: 1972
First Crewed Flight: 1981
End: 2011
Number of Missions: 135
Notes: First missions in which a spacecraft was reused

Type: Program
Start: 1993
First Crewed Flight: 1994
End: 1998

Notes: Russian partnership

Type: Program
Start: 1993
First Crewed Flight: 1998
End: Ongoing
Number of Missions: 65
Notes: Joint with Roscosmos, CSA, ESA, and JAXA; Americans flew on Russian Soyuz after 2011 retirement of Space Shuttle

Type: Program
Start: 2011
First Crewed Flight: 2020
End: Ongoing
Number of Missions: 6
Notes: Current program to shuttle Americans to the ISS

Type: Program
Start: 2017

End: Ongoing

Notes: Current program to bring humans to the Moon again
